devinterp.slt package

Submodules

devinterp.slt.callback module

class devinterp.slt.callback.SamplerCallback(device: device | str = 'cpu')[source]

Bases: object

Base class for creating callbacks used in sample().

Each instantiated callback gets its functions update(), finalize() and sample() called if those exist.

update() happens at every (non burn-in) sample draw, finalize() happens after all draws are finished, and sample() is a helper function that allows access to whatever relevant parameters the callback has computed.

For legibility, each callback can also access parameters in locals() when a class function is called.

Parameters:

device – Device to perform computations on, e.g., ‘cpu’ or ‘cuda’.

devinterp.slt.cov module

class devinterp.slt.cov.BetweenLayerCovarianceAccumulator(model, pairs: Dict[str, Tuple[str, str]], device: device | str = 'cpu', num_evals: int = 3, **accessors: Callable[[Module], Tensor])[source]

Bases: object

A CovarianceAccumulator to compute covariance between arbitrary layers. For use with sample.

Parameters:

  • model – The model to compute covariances on.

  • pairs – Named pairs of layers to compute covariances on.

  • device – Device to perform computations on, e.g., ‘cpu’ or ‘cuda’.

  • num_evals – number of eigenvectors / eigenvalues to return.

  • accessors – Functions to access attention head weights.

class devinterp.slt.cov.CovarianceAccumulator(num_weights: int, accessors: List[Callable[[Module], Tensor]], device: device | str = 'cpu', num_evals: int = 3)[source]

Bases: SamplerCallback

A callback to iteratively compute and store the covariance matrix of model weights. For use with sample.

Parameters:

  • num_weights – Total number of weights.

  • accessors – Functions to access model weights.

  • device – Device to perform computations on, e.g., ‘cpu’ or ‘cuda’.

  • num_evals – Number of eigenvalues to compute.

class devinterp.slt.cov.WithinHeadCovarianceAccumulator(num_heads: int, num_weights_per_head: int, accessors: List[Callable[[Module], Tuple[Tensor, ...]]], device: device | str = 'cpu', num_evals: int = 3)[source]

Bases: object

A CovarianceAccumulator to compute covariance within attention heads. For use with sample.

Parameters:

  • num_heads – The number of attention heads.

  • num_weights_per_head – The number of weights per attention head.

  • accessors – Functions to access attention head weights.

  • device – Device to perform computations on, e.g., ‘cpu’ or ‘cuda’.

  • num_evals – number of eigenvectors / eigenvalues to return.

devinterp.slt.gradient module

class devinterp.slt.gradient.GradientDistribution(num_chains: int, num_draws: int, min_bins: int = 20, param_names: List[str] = None, device: device | str = 'cpu')[source]

Bases: SamplerCallback

Callback for plotting the distribution of gradients as a function of draws.

Parameters:

  • num_draws – Number of samples to draw (should be identical to param passed to sample())

  • num_chains – Number of chains to run (should be identical to param passed to sample())

  • grad_dists – Stores the gradient distributions for each parameter.

  • min_bins – Minimum number of bins for histogram approximation.

  • param_names – List of parameter names to track. If None, all parameters are tracked.

  • bin_size – Size of each bin in the histogram.

  • num_bins – Number of bins in the histogram.

  • min_grad – Minimum gradient value encountered.

  • device – Device to perform computations on, e.g., ‘cpu’ or ‘cuda’.

Raises:

ValueError – If gradients are not computed before calling this callback.

plot(param_name: str, color='blue', plot_zero=True, chain: int = None)[source]

Plots the gradient distribution for a specific parameter.

devinterp.slt.llc module

class devinterp.slt.llc.LLCEstimator(num_chains: int, num_draws: int, n: int, device: device | str = 'cpu')[source]

Bases: SamplerCallback

Callback for estimating the Local Learning Coefficient (LLC) in a rolling fashion during a sampling process. It calculates the LLC based on the average loss across draws for each chain:

\[LLC = \frac{n}{\log(n)} * (avg_loss - init_loss)\]

Parameters:

  • num_chains – Number of chains to run. (should be identical to param passed to sample())

  • num_draws – Number of samples to draw. (should be identical to param passed to sample())

  • n – Number of samples used to calculate the LLC.

  • device – Device to perform computations on, e.g., ‘cpu’ or ‘cuda’.

class devinterp.slt.llc.OnlineLLCEstimator(num_chains: int, num_draws: int, n: int, device: device | str = 'cpu')[source]

Bases: SamplerCallback

Callback for estimating the Local Learning Coefficient (LLC) in an online fashion during a sampling process. It calculates LLCs using the same formula as LLCEstimator, but continuously and including means and std across draws (as opposed to just across chains).

Parameters:

  • num_chains – Number of chains to run. (should be identical to param passed to sample())

  • num_draws – Number of samples to draw. (should be identical to param passed to sample())

  • n – Number of samples used to calculate the LLC.

  • device – Device to perform computations on, e.g., ‘cpu’ or ‘cuda’.

devinterp.slt.loss module

class devinterp.slt.loss.OnlineLossStatistics(base_callback: OnlineLLCEstimator)[source]

Bases: SamplerCallback

Derivative callback that computes various loss statistics for OnlineLLCEstimator. Must be called after the base OnlineLLCEstimator has been called at each draw.

Parameters:

base_callback – Base callback that computes original loss metric.

devinterp.slt.norms module

class devinterp.slt.norms.GradientNorm(num_chains: int, num_draws: int, p_norm: int = 2, device: device | str = 'cpu')[source]

Bases: SamplerCallback

Callback for computing the norm of the gradients of the optimizer / sampler.

Parameters:

  • num_draws – Number of samples to draw. (should be identical to param passed to sample())

  • num_chains – Number of chains to run. (should be identical to param passed to sample())

  • p_norm – Order of the norm to be computed (e.g., 2 for Euclidean norm).

  • device – Device to perform computations on, e.g., ‘cpu’ or ‘cuda’.

class devinterp.slt.norms.NoiseNorm(num_chains: int, num_draws: int, p_norm: int = 2, device: device | str = 'cpu')[source]

Bases: SamplerCallback

Callback for computing the norm of the noise added in the optimizer / sampler.

Parameters:

  • num_draws – Number of samples to draw. (should be identical to param passed to sample())

  • num_chains – Number of chains to run. (should be identical to param passed to sample())

  • p_norm – Order of the norm to be computed (e.g., 2 for Euclidean norm).

  • device – Device to perform computations on, e.g., ‘cpu’ or ‘cuda’.

class devinterp.slt.norms.WeightNorm(num_chains: int, num_draws: int, p_norm: int = 2, device: device | str = 'cpu')[source]

Bases: SamplerCallback

Callback for computing the norm of the weights over the sampling process.

Parameters:

  • num_draws – Number of samples to draw. (should be identical to param passed to sample())

  • num_chains – Number of chains to run. (should be identical to param passed to sample())

  • p_norm – Order of the norm to be computed (e.g., 2 for Euclidean norm).

  • device – Device to perform computations on, e.g., ‘cpu’ or ‘cuda’.

devinterp.slt.sampler module

devinterp.slt.sampler.sample(model: ~torch.nn.modules.module.Module, loader: ~torch.utils.data.dataloader.DataLoader, criterion: ~typing.Callable, sampling_method: ~typing.Type[~torch.optim.optimizer.Optimizer] = <class 'devinterp.optim.sgld.SGLD'>, optimizer_kwargs: ~typing.Dict[str, float | ~typing.Literal['adaptive']] | None = None, num_draws: int = 100, num_chains: int = 10, num_burnin_steps: int = 0, num_steps_bw_draws: int = 1, cores: int = 1, seed: ~typing.List[int] | int | None = None, device: ~torch.device | str = device(type='cpu'), verbose: bool = True, callbacks: ~typing.List[~devinterp.slt.callback.SamplerCallback] = [])[source]

Sample model weights using a given sampling_method, supporting multiple chains/cores, and calculate the observables (loss, llc, etc.) for each callback passed along. After calling this function, the stats of interest live in the callback object.

Parameters:

  • model – The neural network model.

  • loader – DataLoader for input data.

  • criterion – Loss function.

  • sampling_method – Sampling method to use (really a PyTorch optimizer).

  • optimizer_kwargs – Keyword arguments for the PyTorch optimizer (used as sampler here).

  • num_draws – Number of samples to draw.

  • num_chains – Number of chains to run.

  • num_burnin_steps – Number of burn-in steps before sampling.

  • num_steps_bw_draws – Number of steps between each draw.

  • cores – Number of cores for parallel execution.

  • seed – Random seed(s) for sampling. Each chain gets a different (deterministic) seed if this is passed.

  • device – Device to perform computations on, e.g., ‘cpu’ or ‘cuda’.

  • verbose – whether to print sample chain progress

  • callbacks – list of callbacks, each of type SamplerCallback

devinterp.slt.trace module

class devinterp.slt.trace.OnlineTraceStatistics(base_callback: SamplerCallback, attribute: str, device: device | str = 'cpu')[source]

Bases: SamplerCallback

Derivative callback that computes mean/std statistics of a specified trace online. Must be called after the base callback has been called at each draw.

Parameters:

base_callback – Base callback that computes original trace metric online.

devinterp.slt.wbic module

class devinterp.slt.wbic.OnlineWBICEstimator(num_chains: int, num_draws: int, n: int, device: device | str = 'cpu')[source]

Bases: SamplerCallback

Callback for estimating the Widely Applicable Bayesian Information Criterion (WBIC) in an online fashion. The WBIC used here is just \(n\) * (average sampled loss). (Watanabe, 2013)

Parameters:

  • num_draws – Number of samples to draw. (should be identical to param passed to sample())

  • num_chains – Number of chains to run. (should be identical to param passed to sample())

  • n – Number of data points, used in the WBIC calculation.

  • device – Device to perform computations on, e.g., ‘cpu’ or ‘cuda’.
